claim_reports.claim_text: Democracy is a system where citizens have the power to choose their leaders.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence consistently defines democracy as a system where citizens have the power to choose their leaders through competitive elections, as confirmed by multiple high-reliability sources including the Stanford lecture and Freedom House article.

supports.title: What is Democracy?
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly defines democracy as a system where political power is vested in the people, who elect their leaders through competitive elections, thus confirming the claim.
supports.snippet: Democracy is a means for the people to choose their leaders and to hold their leaders accountable for their policies and their conduct in office ...

supports.title: What Is Democracy, and Why Does Defending It Matter?
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence describes democracy as a system where elected representatives are chosen by the people, confirming that citizens have the power to choose their leaders.
supports.snippet: Democracy is a governing system based on the will and consent of the governed, institutions that are accountable to all citizens, adherence to the rule of law,

supports.title: Who Decides What Is Democratic? | Journal of Democracy
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that democracy is fundamentally a system where citizens have the power to choose their leaders, particularly through competitive elections in representative democracies.
supports.snippet: Democracy is a system in which citizens collectively decide by whom and, to some extent, how they will be governed.

supports.title: Democracy - Wikipedia
supports.evidence_summary: The article defines democracy as a system where political power is vested in the people, emphasizing that in a representative democracy, citizens elect their leaders through competitive elections, which aligns with the claim.
supports.snippet: In a representative democracy, the people choose governing officials through elections to do so. The definition of "the people" and the ways authority is shared ...

supports.title: Representative democracy - Wikipedia
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that democracy, specifically representative democracy, is a system where citizens elect representatives to make decisions on their behalf, thereby giving citizens the power to choose their leaders.
supports.snippet: Representative democracy, also known as indirect democracy or electoral democracy, is a type of democracy where elected delegates represent a group of people.

claim_reports.claim_text: Today, democracy is based on the principle that everyone has equal rights and duties.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that democracy is based on the principle of equal rights and duties for all individuals. Multiple high-reliability sources, including the 2023 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices and the Global State of Democracy 2023, emphasize the foundational role of equality and human rights in democratic governance.

supports.title: 2023 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices - State Department
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses the Biden Administration's commitment to advancing equity and equal opportunity for all individuals, emphasizing that the ideal of equal opportunity is foundational to American democracy. It highlights efforts to address systemic disparities and ensure that everyone has equal rights and duties under the law.
supports.snippet: The annual Human Rights Reports cover internationally recognized individual, civil, political, and worker rights, as set forth in the ...

supports.title: [PDF] DEMOCRACY - USEmbassy.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence supports the claim by emphasizing that democracy is based on principles of equality, human rights, and participation, where all individuals have equal rights and duties.
supports.snippet: More specifically, in democracies, these fundamental or inalienable rights include freedom of speech and expression, freedom of religion and conscience, freedom.

supports.title: The Global State of Democracy 2023: The New Checks and Balances
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses the Biden Administration's commitment to advancing equity and equal opportunity for all individuals, particularly those from historically underserved communities, which aligns with the claim that democracy is based on equal rights and duties.
supports.snippet: The global state of democracy in 2023 is complex, fluid and unequal. Across every region of the world, democracy has continued to contract.

supports.title: About democracy and human rights | OHCHR
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence supports the claim by emphasizing that democracy is based on the principles of equality, human rights, and participation, where all individuals have equal rights and duties in governance.
supports.snippet: Respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, including freedom of opinion and expression, and freedom of association; · Access to power and its exercise in ...

supports.title: Democracy and Human Rights in U.S. Foreign Policy - Congress.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses the U.S. government's commitment to advancing equity and equal opportunity for all individuals, particularly those historically marginalized, which aligns with the claim that democracy is based on equal rights and duties.
supports.snippet: U.S. law states that the promotion and protection of democracy and human rights are "principal" and "fundamental" goals of U.S. foreign policy.

supports.title: Democracy - the United Nations
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence supports the claim by emphasizing that democracy is based on the principles of equality, human rights, and participation, stating that 'women and men have equal rights and all people are free from discrimination.'
supports.snippet: The values of freedom, respect for human rights and the principle of holding periodic and genuine elections by universal suffrage are essential elements of ...

claim_reports.claim_text: In ancient Athens, only men who were citizens could vote.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that in ancient Athens, only men who were citizens could vote. Multiple reliable sources confirm that voting rights were restricted to male citizens, excluding women, slaves, and non-citizens from participation.

supports.title: Discussion Series: Athenian Law Lectures
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that in ancient Athens, every citizen had the right to vote, which implies that only male citizens participated in the voting process, aligning with the claim.
supports.snippet: The city of Athens lived under a radically democratic government from 508 until 322 BCE. Before the earlier date there was democracy to be found here and there ...

supports.title: Athenian democracy - Wikipedia
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that in ancient Athens, voting rights were restricted to male citizens, excluding women, slaves, and non-citizens from participating in the democratic process.
supports.snippet: Athenian democracy developed around the 6th century BC in the Greek city-state (known as a polis) of Athens, comprising the city of Athens and the ...

supports.title: Democracy (Ancient Greece) - National Geographic Education
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that in ancient Athens, only citizens participated in the voting process, confirming that only men who were citizens could vote.
supports.snippet: Democracy in ancient Greece served as one of the first forms of self-rule government in the ancient world. The system and ideas employed by ...

supports.title: Lesson 4: Direct Democracy in Ancient Athens
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that in ancient Athens, every citizen had the right to vote on government issues, indicating that only male citizens participated in the voting process.
supports.snippet: Recommended Length: One class period. Key Ideas: Ancient Athenians practiced direct democracy. In direct democracy, every citizen votes on every issue, ...

supports.title: What did it take to become a voting Athenian? : r/AskHistorians
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that only citizens of Athens, specifically landowning men, had the right to vote, aligning with the claim.
supports.snippet: My understanding is that only citizens of Athens could vote--and that a citizen had to be a landowning man. Is this correct?

supports.title: Who was allowed to vote in ancient Athens? - Quora
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that in ancient Athens, only free adult males who were citizens could vote, as citizenship was restricted to those who were land-owning males born in Athens or those who had been granted citizenship for valuable contributions.
supports.snippet: In ancient Athens, Solon divided the male citizens into property thresholds. The Pentikosiomedimnoi were men who were assessed (or paid) 500 ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Civic education plays a crucial role in sustaining democracy.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that civic education is crucial for sustaining democracy, with multiple high-reliability sources emphasizing its role in equipping citizens with the knowledge and skills necessary for informed participation and engagement in democratic processes.

supports.title: Civic Education: The Backbone of Democracy - Ohio Senate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence emphasizes that civic education equips students with essential knowledge to protect democracy and uphold constitutional values, indicating its crucial role in sustaining democracy.
supports.snippet: Civic education provides students with the knowledge needed to protect our republic and uphold our Constitution while also contributing to the needs of the ...

supports.title: [PDF] Advancing Civic Learning and Engagement in Democracy
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that civic education is essential for sustaining democracy, emphasizing that it fosters the knowledge, skills, and dispositions necessary for an informed and responsible citizenry. It argues that without civic education, citizens cannot effectively engage with or uphold democratic values and principles.
supports.snippet: In the pages that follow, the Department outlines directions for advancing civic learning and democratic engagement from grade school to graduate school, with ...

supports.title: A Cry for Help: Civic Education in Today's America
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the importance of civic education in preparing students to participate in democracy, highlighting that an adequate education is necessary for civic engagement and informed voting. It emphasizes the need for a renewed focus on civic education to sustain democracy.
supports.snippet: The Constitution contains an implied right to an education that adequately prepares students to become capable citizens and participate in democracy.

supports.title: An improved civic education will help sustain our democracy
supports.evidence_summary: The article emphasizes the importance of civic education in preparing students to participate effectively in democracy, highlighting that an adequate education is necessary for civic engagement and informed voting.
supports.snippet: Civics includes the formal study of political processes, of the role of government as well as of the rights and responsibilities of citizens.

supports.title: Educating for Democracy: The Case for a New Civics
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that civic education is crucial for sustaining democracy, emphasizing that informed and engaged citizens are necessary for upholding democratic values and processes.
supports.snippet: This situation urgently calls for excellent civic education to foster informed and engaged citizens prepared to uphold democratic values and processes.

supports.title: The need for civic education in 21st-century schools | Brookings
supports.evidence_summary: The article emphasizes the importance of civic education in preparing students to participate effectively in democracy, highlighting that an adequate education is necessary for civic engagement and informed voting.
supports.snippet: Americans' participation in civic life is essential to sustaining our democratic form of government. Without it, a government of the people, by the people, and ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The word democracy comes from ancient Greek meaning citizens power.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that the word 'democracy' comes from ancient Greek, meaning 'citizens' power', as it is derived from 'demos' (people) and 'kratos' (rule or power), confirmed by multiple high-reliability sources including a Stanford article and Britannica.

supports.title: What the ancient Greeks can teach us about democracy
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that the word 'democracy' is derived from the Greek words 'demos' meaning 'people' and 'kratos' meaning 'rule', which aligns with the claim that democracy means citizens' power.
supports.snippet: At the heart of the decision-making process was the “demos” – the Greek word for people – and the “kratos” – the Greek word for rule.

supports.title: Democracy | Definition, History, Meaning, Types, Examples, & Facts
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that the word 'democracy' is derived from the Greek words 'demos' meaning 'people' and 'kratos' meaning 'rule', which aligns with the claim that it means 'citizens power'.
supports.snippet: The term is derived from the Greek dēmokratia, which was coined from dēmos (“people”) and kratos (“rule”) in the middle of the 5th century bce ...

supports.title: Democracy (Ancient Greece) - National Geographic Education
supports.evidence_summary: The source confirms that the word 'democracy' originates from the ancient Greek words 'demos' meaning 'people' and 'kratos' meaning 'rule', which aligns with the claim that it means 'citizens power'.
supports.snippet: The ancient Greeks were the first to create a democracy. The word “democracy” comes from two Greek words that mean people (demos) and rule (kratos).

supports.title: Democracy - Wikipedia
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the word 'democracy' originates from the Ancient Greek terms for 'people' (dēmos) and 'rule' (krátos), which aligns with the claim that it means 'citizens power.'
supports.snippet: The term appeared in the 5th century BC in Greek city-states, notably Classical Athens, to mean "rule of the people", in contrast to aristocracy (ἀριστοκρατία, ...

supports.title: Dispelling Some Myths: Democracy's Roots - Tastes Of History
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that the term 'democracy' comes from the Greek words 'dêmos' meaning 'people' and 'kratos' meaning 'strength' or 'power', which aligns with the claim that democracy means citizens' power.
supports.snippet: The term derives from the words olígos (ὀλίγος) meaning “a few” and archo (ἄρχω) meaning “to rule or to command”. For the ancient Greeks, any ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The French Revolution marked a significant turning point for democracy.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that the French Revolution marked a significant turning point for democracy, as it inspired constitutional reforms and challenged oppressive regimes, influencing democratic systems globally (NBER report, Britannica).

supports.title: [PDF] The Consequences of Radical Reform: The French Revolution
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the French Revolution was a pivotal event that inspired the rise of democracy by challenging oppressive regimes and promoting constitutional reforms, which influenced democratic systems globally.
supports.snippet: Our interpretation is that the Revolution destroyed (the institutional underpinnings of) the power of oligarchies and elites opposed to economic change; ...

supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the French Revolution aimed to transform the relationship between rulers and the governed, which aligns with the idea of a significant turning point for democracy.

claim_reports.claim_text: The idea of universal suffrage emerged during the French Revolution.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents mixed signals regarding the emergence of universal suffrage during the French Revolution. While the Britannica source discusses the establishment of a provisional government during the revolution, the Marxist source notes the abolition of universal suffrage in 1850, indicating that the concept may not have been fully realized during the revolution itself. The JSTOR source references universal suffrage in the context of later elections, further complicating the timeline.

transcript_data.text: what is democracy have you ever wondered how the people in a country get to decide who their leaders are and what rules they should follow this is all about democracy democracy is a system where the citizens of a country have the power to choose their leaders and influence the decisions made by the government the word democracy comes from ancient Greek meaning citizens power let's go back in time to see where this idea started in ient Athens citizens would Gather in an assembly to discuss and decide on laws and other important matters however it wasn't perfect only men who were citizens could vote while women and slaves were excluded fast forward to the 18th century the French Revolution marked a significant Turning Point French citizens overthrew the absolute monarchy and for the first time the idea of universal suffrage emerged this meant that any citizen regardless of wealth could vote however women still couldn't vote at this time over time Democratic ideas spread to many other countries today democracy is based on the principle that everyone has equal rights and duties it's about respecting each other and ensuring that everyone has a say in how the country is run in a democratic system citizens vote to elect their leaders and participate in the decision- making process this is done through elections where people choose their representatives the government is accountable to the people and the rule of law ensures that everyone is treated fairly civic education plays a crucial role in sustaining democracy it teaches citizens about their rights responsibilities and how to participate in the Democratic process this education helps people understand the complexities of political life and how to make informed decisions in summary democracy is about giving power to the people ensuring everyone's voice is heard and maintaining a fair and just Society it's a system that has evolved over centuries and continues to be refined to ensure equality and justice for all
